Expectation1: Avoid gossiping or speaking negatively about others
Situation1: The acquaintance learns a sensitive piece of information about a person that could be used to harm their reputation.
Expectation2: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation2: In the middle of jury instructions, your clerk hands you an alert that the Supreme Court has just issued a ruling that directly overturns the key precedent your current instructions are based on. You must stop immediately.
Story: I was in the middle of delivering jury instructions when my clerk slipped me a note. The Supreme Court had just overturned the very precedent I was explaining. My mind raced—every word I said from this point on could be legally wrong. I felt the weight of my robe, the eyes of the courtroom on me, and the expectation that I would know exactly what to do. At the same time, I remembered the conversation I’d had with an acquaintance just that morning. She’d confided in me about a sensitive matter involving one of the attorneys in this very case. I’d promised myself I wouldn’t gossip, wouldn’t let that information color my judgment or slip out in conversation. Now, as the room waited for my next move, I felt the pressure of both roles: the judge who must be up-to-the-minute on the law, and the acquaintance who must keep confidences and avoid harm. My heart pounded as I stood at the crossroads of these expectations, knowing that whatever I did next would define me in both roles.
